Risks and Assumptions  The recent resumption of armed conflict and instability represent a 
project risk. The eight new project districts have been among the 
worst affected and are active sites for conflict. However, because 
the  insurgents  view  livestock  projects  as  highly  pro-poor  it  is 
expected  that  the  Project  can  operate  in  the  districts  of  the 
ongoing  Third  Livestock  Development  Project—as  it  has  been 
doing during the insurgency—in addition to moving into new ones. 
  
The  Project’s  participatory  planning  approach  will  give  the 
participating  beneficiaries  flexibility  in  selecting  enterprises  and 
ensure  that  the  individual  makes  the  best  possible  choice.  Past 
project  experience  indicates  that  the  risk  of  adverse  producer 
prices  is  minimal,  since  most  of  the  products  are  consumed  or 
marketed  locally,  with  little  outside  competition  at  lower  prices. 
Also,  the  growing  consumption  levels  of  livestock  products  in 
Nepal  indicate  that  household  consumption  and  local  market 
demand  will  readily  dispose  of  the  Project’s  incremental  output 
without  a  significant  adverse  impact  on  producer  prices.  The  risk 
of  the  outbreak  of  animal  diseases  will  be  mitigated  by  the 
increased  use  of  vaccines  supplied  by  community  livestock 
assistants.    The  participatory  processes  used  in  the  Project  will 
minimize  the  risk  that  the  transfer  of  technical  staff  and  funds  to 
the  district  level  as  part  of  the  devolution  process  in  Nepal  will 
exceed district level capacities and resources.

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
 Of  Nepal's  economically  active  population,  84%  are  engaged  in  subsistence-oriented 
agriculture. Farmers keep livestock to provide essential support for agriculture production (draft 
power and compost), nutrition for the family, and household income. Livestock farming is closely 
interrelated  with  crop  production,  management  of  communal  lands,  and  remote  area 
transportation. Animals also are assets that serve as a buffer against risk.  
 
3. 
In 2001 there were approximately 7 million cattle, 3.6 million buffalo, 0.9 million sheep, 
6.5 million goats, 0.9 million pigs, and 19.8 million poultry in Nepal. Nepal has one of the highest 
livestock populations per capita and per unit of cultivable land of any country in Asia. Reliance is 
on low-producing local breeds that are adapted to the environment. Improved livestock accounts 
for  only  8%  of  cattle,  21%  of  buffalo,  6%  of  sheep,  14%  of  goats,  41%  of  pigs,  and  50%  of 
poultry.  These  percentages  are  increasing  as  farmers  in  areas  of  good  access  respond  to 
market  signals  by  introducing  new  animals  and  using  improved  animal  breeds.  In  the  12-year 
period to 1997/98, pig and poultry numbers increased significantly (72 and 79%, respectively). 
Goats (21%), buffalo (18%), and cattle (11%) increased more slowly. Sheep numbers are static, 
as  are  those  of  yak.  Farmers  with  smaller  landholdings  of  between  0.2  and  0.5  hectare  (ha) 
keep almost 25% of the livestock. People who have either no land or own less than 0.2 ha own 
about 11% of the livestock. 
 
The  contribution  of  the  livestock  sector  to  the  agricultural  gross  domestic  product  
4. 
(AGDP) is currently estimated at 31% and is planned to increase to 45% by the latter part of the 
Agriculture Perspective Plan period (1995-2015). Dairy is the most important livestock activity, 
accounting  for  62.7%  of  the  total  livestock  sector  contribution  to  AGDP,  followed  by  meat 
(32.4%) and eggs (5.0%). Growth performance in the agriculture sector varies and the share of 
its  subsectors  has  changed  over  time.  During  1995-1996  to  1999-2000,  the  share  of  food 
grains, cash crops, livestock, and fisheries increased, whereas that of other crops and forestry 
declined.  The  better  performing  subsectors  were  fisheries  (9.7%),  cash  crops  (5.6%),  and 
livestock (3.6%). In contrast, the growth rate for food grains was 2.3%, other crops 3.0%, and 
forestry 0.3%. Livestock (animals and products) exports are 0.2% of total exports and 1.1% of 
total  imports,  and  11.4%  and  6.1%  of  agricultural  sector  exports  and  imports,  respectively. 
Income from livestock is high as a proportion of total income, particularly for poorer farmers over 
20% of whose income is from livestock, compared with around 9% for wealthier farmers.  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
The  livestock  subsector  recorded  healthy  growth  during  the  1990s  and  averaged  over 
5. 
3%  growth  annually,  accelerating  from  1.6%  during  the  first  half  of  the  decade  to  3.6%  in  the 
second  half.  It  is  a  fast-growing  agriculture  subsector  and  is  considered  important  in  poverty 
reduction.  The  Agriculture  Perspective  Plan  targets  the  livestock  subsector  as  an  engine  for

the  livestock  subsector  in  national  development,  recognizing  that  it  tends  to  redistribute  urban 
wealth to the rural areas. The current Tenth Plan (2002-2007) seeks to bring about a substantial

6. 
Development through livestock can reach over 80% of the rural population. The livestock 
subsector  is  one  of  the  key  entry  points  for  programs  to  reach  the  rural  poor  and,  if  correctly 
oriented  to  small  animals,  its  development  favors  disadvantaged  groups,  such  as  women  and 
poorer farmers. Livestock needs to be brought more fully into the farming system as a revenue 
source  in  its  own  right,  rather  than  just  to  support  crop  enterprises.  At  present,  extension  and 
animal  health  support  are  insufficient  due  to  poor  area  coverage,  and  use  of  inputs  is 
constrained by a lack of awareness among communities and . Current returns to labor are low: 
from  about  $0.11  per  day  and  averaging  $0.53,  or  about  $40  per  year  for  poor  families. 
Livestock  development  is  also  environmentally  neutral,  contributing  to  land  stability  and  soil 
improvement  from  forage,  reduced  pressure  on  grazing  lands  from  stall-feeding  systems,  and 
reduced dependence on forest resources through the use of biogas. Women undertake 70% of 
the  work  and  make  many  of  the  decisions  associated  with  livestock  keeping;  therefore,  key 
issues continue to be providing animal health and production services (including microfinance) 
to men and women farmers and improving the ability to use the services; and greater attention 
to the gender balance of farmer groups, umbrella organizations, and cooperatives.  
  
The recent Asian Development Bank (ADB) Nepal Livestock Sector Review2 concluded 
7. 
that,  while  the  livestock  subsector  is  very  complex,  with  many  crosscutting  issues  and 
interrelationships with other sectors, it is a very important part of the agriculture sector and has 
a key role to play in the country's development and in poverty reduction. While a great deal of 
progress  has  been  made  over  the  last  30  years  and  innovative  new  approaches  have  been 
developed,  new  approaches  are  still  needed.  Future  development  must  include  (i)  more 
effective social enhancement (strengthening of farmer organizations, and self-determination); (ii) 
institutional strengthening (changed attitudes, including sensitivity to issues of gender and social 
exclusion, improved  capabilities,  and  levels  of  cooperation  by  government  services-providers); 
(iii)  increased  commercialization  involving  market  chain  development,  value  addition,  import 
substitution, and greater participation of the private sector; and (iv) improved coordination and 
support among government, the private sector, and aid agencies. The subsector analysis is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
Between 1980 and 2003 ADB supported three livestock development projects with loans 
8. 
totaling  $37  million  (Appendix  2).3  The  projects  covered  24  of  the  75  districts  of  Nepal.  Still

areas that the recent insurgency has been most pronounced and where livestock development 
will help meet some of the frustrated expectations of communities.

10.  While  the  national  incidence  of  poverty  is  42%,  incidence  in  the  majority  of  the  project 
districts  is  estimated  at  60%.  Poverty  is  highest  among  the  disadvantaged  castes  (68%)  and 
ethnic minorities (58%). Poverty reduction through livestock involves reducing risks for the poor, 
improving  food  security,  improving  levels  of  nutrition  and  incomes,  improving  livelihoods,  and 
providing  an  effective  asset  buffer  against  adversity.  Small  animals  purchased  locally  with 
microfinance,  supported  by  improved  animal  health  services,  improved  levels  of  feeding,  and 
increased  knowledge  of  animal  husbandry  methods  and  marketing  provide  poor  farm 
households with the means to reduce poverty. Livestock production, processing, and marketing 
are  a  base  for  entrepreneurial  activity  and  stimulate  job  creation.  Milk,  for  example,  has  an 
employment multiplier effect of around 8:1. 
 
11. 
Unequal development, economic disparity, crisis in governance, high underemployment, 
rural poverty, social exclusion, and gender discrimination have produced a fertile ground for the 
recent conflict to take root in rural communities, particularly in the Mid-Western Region. There 
has  been  significant  migration  to  towns  in  search  of  protection  and  social  services.  Other 
families  have  been  completely  displaced.  For  those  who  stayed,  the  conflict  has  affected 
household  work  and  productivity,  increased  household  expenses,  and  led  to  domestic  stress. 
Affected communities have indicated that they should be mobilized and unified in their efforts to 
participate in effective income generation and employment programs, and be trained to improve 
their capabilities and capacities. 
 
12. 
Nepal is a rapidly urbanizing country where 50% of the population (30 million) will live in 
urban  areas  by  2035  (20%  or  4  million  currently  live  in  urban  areas).  The  rural  population  will 
come  under  increasing  pressure  to  supply  urban  consumers  with  their  meat,  milk,  and  egg 
requirements. Nepal imports approximately half its current requirements for meat and milk, and 
import substitution is a national objective. The marketing of live animals and meat is undertaken 
entirely  by  the  private  sector  and  is  reasonably  efficient,  although  quality  standards  require 
improvement. Marketed milk is either locally produced milk or processed milk reconstituted from 
imported milk powder. The formal milk marketing system shows marked seasonal differences in 
production,  and  oversupply  occurs  in  some  months.  Where  milk  collection  is  not  possible, 
seasonal surpluses are converted to butter. 
 
13. 
DLS  has  had  the  experience  of  implementing  three  major  ADB  loans  for  livestock 
development, and participated in several other smaller projects over the last 20 years (Appendix 
2).  There  is  a  history  of  successful  experiences  and  innovation  on  which  to  base  further 
development  activity  (paras.  7–9).  DLS  is  considered  one  of  the  more  innovative  government 
departments  in  Nepal  and  is  more  attuned  to  development  priorities.  It  has  pioneered  several 

  4

innovations  such  as  public-private  partnerships,  cross-sectoral  cooperation,  and  small-scale 
entrepreneur  development.  DLS  has  the  technical  competence  to  implement  another  project, 
but  the  changes  in  managerial  ability,  role  orientation,  cross-sectoral  linkages,  extension 
capability, and competence started under the TLDP need to be continued and reinforced. DLS 
constraints  also  include  a  staff-to-farming  household  ratio  of  1:2,000,  insufficient  training  for 
technical  staff,  lack  of  specialization,  mobility  problems,  weak  monitoring  and  evaluation 
capacity,  and  an  input-driven  orientation  as  opposed  to  a  demand-  and  output-driven  outlook 
that public-private partnerships can address.  
 
14. 
Several  policy  issues  identified  in  the  ADB  Nepal  Livestock  Subsector  Review  require 
attention.  They  include  (i)  giving  equal  opportunities  to  livestock  industries,  which  are  treated 
differently  from  agriculture  industries  in  the  value-added  tax,  tax  exemption,  discounted 
electricity  charges,  bank  interest  rates,  and  import  duties;  (ii)  enforcing  existing  legislation  on 
product  quality  control,  hygiene,  and  environmental  management;  and  (iii)  privatizing  facilities 
and  services  that  the  private  sector  can  undertake.  Privatization  of  the  Pokhara  Milk  Supply 
Scheme and the future role of the Dairy Development Corporation in the subsector are issues 
that need to be resolved. The Government has prepared a time-bound action plan to address 
these policy issues. 
 
15. 
The intent of national plans, the views of poverty and conflict-affected communities, the 
recommendations of the subsector review, and the ADB country program strategy all recognize 
the need for a livestock project with a poverty reduction focus, one that meets the needs of the 
poor,  particularly  poor  women;  effectively  links  production  and  marketing;  creates  jobs;  and 
meets urban market requirements for meat, milk, and eggs currently supported by imports. The 
project design is consistent with these objectives.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

 

16. 
The Project aims to reduce poverty among poor rural men and women through gender 
and  socially  inclusive  development.  Its  purpose  will  be  to  improve  levels  of  food  security, 
nutrition, incomes, and employment from livestock production and small-scale livestock related 
enterprises in 48 districts (all 5 development regions) of Nepal (map, page vii). The Project will 
benefit  164,000  families  through  increased  productivity  of  the  livestock  subsector  in  an 
environmentally sustainable and socially equitable manner, while enhancing the capacity of men 
and women to manage the development process. The project framework is in Appendix 3. The 
project concept and area are described in Appendix 4. 
 
B. 

Components and Outputs 

The  project  comprises  five  components:  (i)  community  development  and  capacity 
17. 
building,  (ii)  livestock  productivity  improvement,  (iii)  livestock  processing  and  marketing,  (iv)  a 
livelihoods pilot program for higher altitudes, and (v) project management services. 
 

1. 

Community Development and Capacity Building 

18.

where  they  contribute  significantly  to  the  Project's  goal  and  purpose.  Experience  in  the  TLDP 
has been that for communities to benefit from livestock productivity improvement programs, they 
must  be  made  more  aware  of  their  rights  and  responsibilities,  and  risks,  and  have  their 
competency  levels  raised  before  development  activities  begin.  The  project  design  recognizes

Community Development 

 
19. 
DLS  will  work  in  partnership  with  local  NGOs,  and  district  and  village  development 
committees (DDCs and VDCs) in 22 districts to undertake poverty and social mapping to identify 
and  target  poorer  and  disadvantaged  communities,  and  intensive  livestock  development

20. 
Targeted  communities  in  approximately  690  selected  intensive  livestock  development 
pockets will be informed of project opportunities, their responsibilities and risks associated with 
participation, and the rights of communities through awareness programs run by NGO partners. 
The NGOs, supported by DLS, will assess the training needs of communities (male and female),

education  (embracing  technology,  legal  literacy,  and  basic  agribusiness).  Training  will 
strengthen farmer organizations and farmer capabilities. It will focus on leadership, records and 
bookkeeping, financial savings, meeting procedures, animal health and production technology, 
forage development, and local-level marketing. 
 
The  capacity  of  district-level  organizations—CBOs  and  NGOs—to  participate  in  the 
21.

increase  the  participation  of  women  and  the  poor),  livestock  enterprise  activity,  and 
microfinance  to  (i)  improve  their  performance  as  project  partners,  (ii)  encourage  balanced

22. 
Concurrently,  awareness  of  the  Project’s  aims  and  activities,  and  new  roles  and 
responsibilities  will  be  raised  among  DLS  staff  and  key  staff  in  the  project  DDCs.  Project 
orientation  programs  will  be  held,  followed  by  a  three-module  package  of  training  that  will 
include (i) social mobilization; (ii) improving animal production, and agribusiness; and (iii) basic 
principles of animal and product processing, and marketing.  
 
23. 
Approximately  3,450  farmer  groups,  comprising  at  least  35%  women  in  mixed  groups, 
with 20 households per group will be formed after social mobilization activities. Communities will 
select an enterprise from a menu of 15 livestock enterprises, and groups will be formed around 
shared interests, such as poultry and goat groups. Group members will agree on an objective, 
prepare  an  action  plan,  and  commit  to  a  savings  program.  Elected  group  leaders  will  receive 
training  in  leadership,  monitoring,  evaluation,  and  bookkeeping  to  improve  the  efficiency  and 
transparency  of  group  activities.  All  group  members  will  receive  enterprise  education  training. 
An  umbrella  committee  will  coordinate  the  activity  of  5-10  groups  to  address  any  production-
related  or  input  and  output  supply  problems,  consider  the  growth  of  small  economic  units 
(groups) into larger legally recognized economic units (cooperative societies), address broader 
community needs, and liaise with lower levels of administration such as VDCs and DDCs.

2. 

Livestock Productivity Improvement 

29. 
Fifteen  livestock  improvement  models  have  been  identified  as  suitable  for  small  and 
resource-poor  farmers.  Thus,  the  69,000  men  and  women  farmers  participating  in  the  22 
intensive  production  districts  will  have  a  degree  of  choice  in  selecting  project  activities. 
Emphasis will be on smaller investments such as forages, goats, calf rearing, pigs, and poultry 
to enable a higher proportion of poorer families (including women and disadvantaged groups) to 
participate. Financial savings by beneficiaries will be promoted. 
 
30. 
Training  is  proposed  for  feed  millers,  poultry  farmers,  and  feed  ingredient  suppliers  to 
improve the standard of feed formulation. Feed standards will be reviewed, and the Department 
of Food Technology and Quality Control and DLS will undertake quality control with 520 district-
level  staff  being  trained  in  this  area.  Approximately  20  entrepreneurs  will  be  assisted  to 
establish  small-scale  feed  mill  operations  in  the  intensive  livestock  production  areas,  with 
emphasis on using forage legumes to replace imported protein ingredients. Better quality feeds 
will benefit all producers, including the poor. Loans will also be provided for biogas digesters, in 
cooperation with the Biogas Support Program.  
 
31. 
Forage-led development will involve importing new genetic stock, demonstrating species 
and their management to farmers, and establishing a viable forage seed industry. DLS district 
staff  will  extend  forage  technologies  and  management  to  farmers  using  the  successful 
strategies developed under the TLDP. DLS staff will be trained in seed production systems and 
technologies suitable for adoption in Nepal.  
 
RMDC and its network of MFIs will provide microfinance credit. A total of 100 MFIs are 
32. 
likely partners. RMDC or a specialized training institution will train 60 less experienced MFIs to 
provide microfinance services in six project districts currently without such services. Borrowers 
are  more  likely  to  be  women;  therefore  training  will  emphasize  gender  issues  related  to 
microfinance. An equity contribution of 10% in the form of labor is expected from small farmers 
borrowing to establish their selected enterprise. Improvement in microfinance performance will 
be facilitated through a program of training for MFIs, farmer leaders, and DLS district staff.  
 

3. 

Livestock Processing and Marketing  

33. 
This component aims to develop small-scale and localized processing and marketing of 
livestock  products  for  the  benefit  of  producers.  The  component  will  create  employment  and 
improve product quality. Microcredit for small enterprises will be made available to commercial 
banks through RMDC. Approximately 1,050 small enterprises will be created, with investments 
ranging  from  live  animal  markets  to  milk  chilling  centers,  milk  processing  facilities,  slaughter 
slabs,  meat  shops,  and  para-veterinary  practices.  The  enterprises  are  estimated  to  provide  at 
least 5,100 person-years of permanent employment. The project initiatives will be demand-led 
and  private-sector  based.  Where  possible,  local  bodies  (municipalities  and  DDCs)  and  private 
sector entrepreneurs will be encouraged to develop integrated market facilities to be known as 
the  livestock  commercial  center  approach.  Awareness-raising  activities,  market  supply  and 
demand appraisals, market linkage analyses, and stakeholder participatory planning exercises 
will precede market development activities. A range of training will be available to improve the 

  8

skills  of  those  already  involved  in  processing  and  marketing,  and  to  bring  new  entrepreneurs 
into the business. 
 
34. 
In  at  least  22  livestock  commercial  centers,    existing  live  animal  markets  will  be 
improved  and  new  markets  developed.  Approximately  2,400  farmer  leaders,  of  which  at  least 
35%  will  be  women—in  accordance  with  the  Government’s  policy  of  promoting  a  minimum  of 
35% women’s participation in all development activities—will be made aware of how they may 
extend their influence along the market chain to the markets, and 1,680 farmers and traders will 
receive  training  in  market  management.  The  Project  will  provide  assistance  to  improve  the 
quality and hygiene standards of slaughter, meat handling, and meat selling.  
 
35. 
The Project will provide credit for 370 new dairy enterprises comprising chilling centers, 
small-scale and cottage dairies, and cold chain retail outlets. The strategy will be to encourage 
entrepreneurial activity in and around district towns and to provide consumers with an increased 
supply of improved products. A significant campaign to raise farmer awareness of milk hygiene 
will be undertaken along with new dairy entrepreneur training, milk processor training, milk plant 
maintenance,  and  milk  product  quality  management.  As  in  the  TLDP,  the  objective  will  be  to 
stimulate local processing and marketing microenterprises, generate employment, and increase 
the supply of products to meet the demand of consumers in rural towns.  
 
It  has  become  clear  from  the  TLDP  that  processing  and  marketing  initiatives  may  be 
36. 
limited by low levels of consumer responsiveness and that consumer awareness and education 
programs must run parallel with market development activities. The Project will support a series 
of  mass  media  programs  directed  at  urban  consumers  to  make  consumers  more  aware  of 
hygiene  and  quality  issues,  and  the  reasons  behind  market  improvement  initiatives.  The 
outcome, as has been indicated by TLDP experience, is appreciation by consumers of quality 
assurance systems, and increased demand for improved quality products. 
 
As  the  demand  for  animal  health  and  production  services  in  commercialized  farming 
37. 
areas is outstripping the ability of DLS to provide services, farmers show a strong demand for 
the services of private para-veterinary personnel. Based on TLDP’s successful experience and 
needs, the Project will support the establishment of 250 para-veterinarians. DLS will be assisted 
to link with and provide training to strengthen private sector organizations. Technical assistance 
will be provided to the new Directorate of Livestock Marketing Promotion to develop policies and 
action plans, and to build working linkages with the private sector.

Livelihoods Pilot Program for Higher Altitudes 

38.

Economic Impacts

64. 
The  main  project  benefits  will  be  the  incremental  production  and  sale  of  milk,  milk 
products, meat, eggs, forage, seeds, and animals that will be consumed by the beneficiaries or 
sold  in  local  markets.  Household  incomes  are  expected  to  increase  by  50%  from  the  current 
average of $40 per year, and levels of family nutrition to improve by 20%.  
 
65. 
Intermediate  outputs  will  be  increased  forage  and  feed  supplies  that  improve  animal 
health and productivity, improved care of existing livestock, and reduced risks associated with 
animal  keeping.  Increased  meat  and  milk  supplies  will  be  available  to  consumers;  support

local NGOs and MFIs will be strengthened. The livestock processing and marketing component 
will  create  permanent  employment  opportunities  of  about  5,100  person-years,  and  improve 
access  to  markets  and  farmers’  market  awareness  for  about  95,000  households.  The  Project 
will  provide  environmental  benefits  in  the  form  of  dung  for  use  as  crop  fertilizer  and  domestic 
fuel,  and  in  biogas  production.  The  Project  will  also  provide  consumer  benefits  in  the  form  of 
milk, meat, and milk and meat products of improved hygiene and quality.

Poverty Reduction Impacts 
 
Poor  farm  families  will  be  offered  a  choice  of  one  of  several  livestock  enterprises  that 
67. 
match their needs, resources, and circumstances. Group strategies will result in high adoption 
rates of individual enterprises by farmers. The Project will reach 69,000 poorer farming families, 
while processing activities will be offered to 95,000 families. There are approximately 1.1 million 
farming households in the project area, of which 49% are below the poverty line. The Project will 
reach about 50% of poverty-affected communities in production pockets in the project area. The 
Project  will  particularly  target  landless  households  headed  by  women,  and  disadvantaged 
groups  such  as  ex-bonded  laborers  and  low  caste  families.  Low-cost  enterprises  have  been 
specifically developed to facilitate access of the target groups to income-generating activities.  
 
68. 
Expected impacts of livestock enterprises on poverty have been examined. Agricultural 
production benefits generally accrue to the owners of the land, but there are additional expected 
increments to household income through more efficient labor use with the Project. Assuming the 
degree of unemployment and underemployment typical of the districts of west Nepal, in financial 
terms  this  improved  return  to  labor  (measured  as  returns  per  day)  will  add  50%  to  poor 
households’ income and raise them above the poverty line.  
 
69. 
Access  to  a  regular  and  usable  flow  of  financial  and  social  resources  provided  by  the 
Project  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  by  (i)  raising  beneficiaries’  levels  of  empowerment, 
particularly  with  regard  to  accessing  services;  (ii)  increasing  the  number  of  organized  farmer 
(female  and  male)  groups  and  ward-level  associations;  (iii)  increasing  household  incomes 
through  employment  generation;  (iv)  improving  the  nutritional  status  of  households  through 
consumption of livestock and dairy products; (v) increasing women’s employment, participation, 
and  self-determination;  and  (vi)  encouraging  the  growth  of  environment-friendly  economic 
enterprises. A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10.

Environmental Impacts 
 
74. 
An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  has  indicated  that  the  mountainous  terrain 
and high-intensity rainfall during the monsoon coupled with high population pressure from both 
humans  and  livestock  lead  to  land  degradation  in  the  midhills  in  the  form  of  soil  loss  from 
slopes,  landslides,  and  erosion.  None  of  the  surveyed  households  had  any  waste  treatment 
system, nor had they any precise understanding of the effects of a degraded environment. The 
Project  will  promote  stall-feeding  or  tethered  systems  for  larger  animals  and  semi-scavenging 
and stall-feeding systems for goats. The by-products from these enterprises will be recycled as 
crop  fertilizer,  or  used  as  domestic  fuel.  Growing  of  fodder  trees  also  contributes  fuelwood, 
which  significantly  reduces  pressure  on  forests.  The  Project  will  facilitate  funding  for  biogas 
digesters  to  reduce  dependence  on  burning  dung  for  fuel.  The  environmental  impacts  of  the 
production activities are expected to be insignificant. The NGO and farmer training programs will 
include  education  on  environmental  responsibilities  and  management  to  develop  community 
consciousness of environmental issues that will extend beyond the life of the Project, including 
the  need  to  preserve  existing  biodiversity.  The  design  of  markets,  slaughter  slabs,  and  milk 
treatment  facilities  will  include  effective  and  environmentally  sound  waste  and  water  disposal 
systems, with adequate budget to construct the required environmental protection facilities. The 
project enterprise activities are expected to have minimal adverse impact on the environment;

therefore MFIs do not need to apply an environmental management system. However, DLS will 
constitute  an  IEE  team  to  screen  processing  and  marketing  subprojects,  and  prepare  reports

training  programs  will  significantly  assist  in  developing  better  environment  management 
practices in rural areas. A summary IEE is in Appendix 12.

LIVESTOCK SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

1. 
Nepal  is  a  rural  country  with  a  population  of  23  million.  Of  the  economically  active 
population,  84%  are  engaged  in  subsistence-oriented  agriculture  based  on  crop-livestock,  or 
crop-livestock-forest  integrated  farming  systems.  Livestock  farming  is  closely  interrelated  with 
crop production, forest management, management of communal lands, and transportation. Most 
farmers  keep  livestock,  and  animals  are  an  essential  part  of  rural  landscape  management, 
farming systems, and the household economy. 
 
2. 
The  contribution  of  the  livestock  sector  to  the  agricultural  gross  domestic  product  is 
estimated to be 31% and is expected to increase to 45% toward the latter part of the Agriculture 
Perspective Plan period. Dairy is the most important livestock component, contributing 62.7% of 
the  livestock  share  in  the  agricultural  gross  domestic  product,  followed  by  meat  (32.4%)  and 
eggs  (5.0%).  Livestock  exports  (animals  and  products)  are  0.2%  of  total  exports  and  1.1%  of 
total imports, and 11.4% and 6.1% of agricultural sector exports and imports, respectively. 
 
The  livestock  subsector  recorded  healthy  annual  growth  during  the  1990s,  averaging 
3. 
over 3%, accelerating from 1.6% during the first half of the decade to 3.6% in the second half. It 
is  one  of  the  faster  growing  agricultural  subsectors  and  is  considered  an  important  tool  in 
poverty  reduction,  offering  the  poor  family  nutrition,  income,  asset  development,  and  asset 
buffering  against  adversity.  However,  its  growth  reflects  a  growing  population's  propensity  to 
keep  livestock,  rather  than  any  significant  increase  in  livestock  productivity.  Individual  projects 
lead to productivity improvements but they need to be widely replicated nationwide. 
 
Low  animal  productivity  is  associated  with  underfeeding  (by  about  one  third),  poor 
4. 
genetic quality in milk- or meat-producing animals, low levels of management, and inadequate 
extension  services  (animal  health,  animal  husbandry,  feeding,  and  agribusiness).  Where 
farmers  are  supplied  with  necessary  services,  increases  in  productivity  do  occur;  however, 
staffing  and  budgetary  constraints  limit  the  Government’s  ability  to  expand  this  effect 
nationwide. The need to develop private sector-based services to work alongside those of the 
Government is becoming more urgent. 
 
The  increasing  rate  of  urbanization  will  result  in  half  of  Nepal’s  population  being 
5. 
urbanized within 25 years. An increasing population and rising urban incomes will significantly 
increase the demand for milk, meat, and eggs. This demand will place significant pressure on 
farmers to move from subsistence to more commercialized systems of production. Only half the 
urban requirement for milk and meat is being met by local production at the moment; the rest is 
being  imported.  The  Project's  emphasis  on  improving  animal  productivity  recognizes  the 
growing pressure on local production and imports. 
 
As the population grows and available land resources are divided among the population, 
6. 
rural families have increasingly found it difficult to support themselves on a shrinking individual 
share  of  the  agricultural  base.  Men  are  being  compelled  to  migrate  for  work  to  support  their 
families,  while  women  must  contribute  as  best  they  can  to  family  enterprises  in  rural 
homesteads. The effect in some areas has been either depopulation of livestock or a reduction 
in  its  performance.  The  need  for  social,  economic,  or  enterprise  education  to  underpin  family 
enterprise  activity  is  of  increasing  importance.  The  community  development  and  capacity 
building component of the Project addresses this issue. 
 
7. 
The  recent  conflict  in  Nepal  has  affected  everyone  at  village  level  with  destruction  of 
infrastructure  and  a  reduction  in  employment  and  jobs.  Migration  to  towns  in  search  of

disparity, political frustration, crisis in governance, justice being denied to the poor, and poverty

With the aim of improving incomes and employment, the Project has selected eight of the worst

The  presence  at  Nepal’s  border  of  a  large  market  in  India  represents  an  opportunity 
rather than a threat, providing Nepal can increase the volume and consistency of production by 
aggregation  of  individual  producers’  production,  improving  supply  chains  from  producer  to

direction will start with the livestock processing component of the Project to address quality and 
processing improvement.  
 
9. 
Nepal became a signatory to the World Trade Organization in October 2003. To access 
the  benefits  of  World  Trade  Organization  membership,  overall  investment  in  agriculture, 
including  livestock,  will  have  to  improve—better  infrastructure,  improved  animal  productivity, 
improved financial systems, market information systems, and quality certification. A number of 
changes  are  required:  (i)  less  dependence  on  imports  of  live  animals  for  slaughter,  and  milk 
powder; (ii) increased exports of higher value semiprocessed products such as dairy products, 
hides, and skins; (iii) improved agroprocessing of domestically produced milk, meat, and fibers, 
and  imported  raw  materials  (such  as  wool  for  carpets);  (iv)  stronger  producer-processor-
consumer  supply  chain  linkages;  and  (v)  the  emergence  of  niche  marketing  with  high  value 
added and brand recognition. The Project addresses each of these issues. 
 
10. 
It is estimated that during the next decade, the annual milk demand of the urban sector 
will  grow  by  11.1%.  This  estimate  is  based  on  (i)  trends  in  demand  over  the  last  10  years  for 
processed fluid milk, (ii) urban population growth of 5.2% in milk-buying municipalities, and (iii) a 
family consumption income elasticity of 1.5%. On this basis, milk production of 1.1 million metric 
tons  in  2001  needs  to  increase  to  3  million  metric  tons  in  2010/11.  This  indicates  that  the 
present  annual  growth  rate  in  milk  production  must  increase  from  around  3%  to  17%  (when 
imports are excluded) to meet the demand of larger urban centers.

programs for farmers, collectors, and processors in the marketing chain.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS    

Economic Rationale  

 
A. 
 
In Nepal, the livestock subsector contributes 31% to agricultural gross domestic product 
1. 
(AGDP).    More  than  80%  of  the  economically  active  population  is  engaged  in  crop-livestock- 
forest  integrated  farming  systems.    A  significant  proportion  of  small  farmers  and  the  landless 
keep a higher proportion of livestock.  Livestock plays a vital role in food security for the poor: it 
is the only source of high value protein in the diet and provides 20% of total household income 
in the hills. 

2. 
The  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  reduce  the  poverty  of  farm  families  in  the  western 
districts  of  Nepal.  Recent  poverty  assessments  show  that  poverty  incidence  and  severity  are 
greatest  in  the  west.  The  existing  farming  system  suffers  from  low  animal  productivity, 
inadequate access to effective extension services, lack of affordable credit, and limited market 
opportunities.  With the Project, impacts will derive from separate but closely linked sources—a 
technical response to improved extension and animal health services and a financial response 
from access to affordable investment credit. Market distortions will also be addressed through a 
progressive reduction of government controls and promotion of community and private sector-
led  interventions—improved  service  delivery,  better  hygiene  standards  and  quality  control—at 
the level of both input supplies and availability of processed products.  

 

 

1. 

Demand Analysis 

3. 
The Project will have a direct impact on the lives of 69,000 beneficiary smallholder farm 
families  in  690  production  pockets.  In  addition,  the  wider  rural  economy  will  benefit  through 
enhanced  food  production  and  additional  employment  opportunities.  Investment  in  livestock 
processing  and  marketing  enterprises  will  provide  employment  and  expanded  trading 
opportunities for about 95,000 households. Cash incomes will increase and food insecurity will 
be  significantly  reduced.  Farmers  will  benefit  from  access  to  improved  livestock  extension 
services, which will result in improved and sustainable productivity. Project impacts will be the 
result  of  a  combination  of  social  preparation,  improved  feeding,  animal  health,  extension 
services, and access to microfinance.  
 
 
 
4. 
The  output  from  the  Project  will  comprise  milk,  meat,  and  eggs.  The  linkages  between 
production and marketing will be improved by promoting local processing and marketing. Eggs 
and milk will generally be sold in the local area. Live animals are likely to be consumed locally, 
or sold to livestock traders.   
 
5. 
The  formal  milk  collection  system  initiated  by  the  Dairy  Development  Corporation,  and 
now  including  private  sector  entrepreneurs,  has  been  effective  in  collecting  milk  from  a  wide 
area for sale in Kathmandu and other major towns (accounting, however, for only 10% of total 
milk production). Experience in implementing the Third Livestock Development Project (TLDP) 
has  shown  that  secondary  towns  are  a  ready  market  for  milk  and  milk  products.  It  has  also 
demonstrated  that  small  dairies  with  low-cost  technology  are  financially  viable  and  create 
employment. It is estimated that during the next decade, the annual milk demand from the urban 
sector  will  grow  by  11%.  The  Project  will  follow  the  TLDP  approach  of  promoting  local 
processing  and  marketing,  with  emphasis  on  traditional  dairy  product  diversification.  Meat 
consumption  is  increasing  because  of  urbanization  and  rising  incomes,  but  there  is  a  growing 
gap between supply and demand. It is estimated that national meat demand will reach 453,000 
metric tons in 2010, whereas the present level of production is below 200,000 metric tons, only

Tibet and India and meat from overseas. On average, 150,000 head of buffalo, 300,000 goats,

under  the  Project  will  meet  a  ready  market  within  Nepal.  Specialist  private  sector  producers,

Sector Policy Context 

2. 

 

Approach and Methodology 

6. 
Currently, the increasing urban demand for milk and milk products is met by imports of 
milk powder and milk products. In 2000/01 12,568 metric tons of dairy products were imported. 
The import volume, with a liquid milk equivalent of 100-120 million liters of milk, was similar to 
the  volume  of  locally  processed  milk  currently  marketed  by  the  formal  sector  in  Nepal.    Local 
production  capacity  is  not  presently  able  to  meet  the  rising  demand  for  milk.  Poor  quality 
subsidized skim milk powder, and milk (55,000 liters per day) from India are meeting the local 
production deficit  of  60%.  The  demand  for  processed  milk  in  Nepal  is  estimated  at  0.5  million 
liters per day against the local production of 0.2 million liters. The Project addresses this market 
distortion  through  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  to  deregulate  milk  pricing,  which  is 
influenced by the Dairy Development Corporation’s market operations. Related reforms include 
enforcing  legislation  pertaining  to  meat  and  animal  feed  quality,  and  removing  tax  and  duty 
distortions  in  the  livestock  industry.  Reorientation  of  the  Department  of  Livestock  Services  is 
also envisaged to strengthen its capability in community development and extension, monitoring 
and  evaluation,  and  market  surveillance.  Additionally,  private  sector  institutions  will  be 
supported to take responsibility for quality assurance.

7. 
To  determine  the  expected  direct  benefits  of  project  livestock  enterprises,  where 
appropriate,  quantifiable  effects  are  valued  by  comparing  the  with-  and  without-project 
scenarios.  Many  enterprises  will  be  entirely  new  to  farmers,  in  which  case  all  benefits  are 
regarded  as  incremental.  In  addition  to  the  quantifiable  benefits  and  costs  included  in  the 
analysis,  the  Project  can  have  nonquantifiable  effects.  Community  mobilization,  for  example, 
can result in women acquiring skills and confidence to participate more actively in village affairs. 
The increase in farm household incomes and improved food security will also result in improved 
nutrition and health status among the target beneficiaries.  
 
Prices and data used in the analysis were obtained from a variety of secondary sources, 
8. 
farmer  interviews,  and  TLDP  monitoring  data.  Assumptions  used  in  the  economic  analysis 
follow: (i) import parity pricing for milk products is used; (ii) border pricing is used for buffalo and

exchange rate of NRs76/$1 is used; (v) for nontraded goods and services, specific conversion

goats  and  larger  ruminants  will  be  encouraged.  Environment-friendly  biogas  technology  will 
receive priority in the animal production districts, and microfinance will be provided to farmers. 
Livestock  enterprises  being  offered  to  communities  are  those  that  poor  families,  women,  and 
disadvantaged groups have already expressed interest in adopting. 
 
3. 
A second component of the project concerns processing and marketing of livestock and 
their products. The component covers an area of about 22 districts with 2.4 million households, 
of which 95,000 are expected to benefit. In these districts commercialized livestock production 
units  are  emerging  along  roadsides  and  within,  and  adjacent  to,  urban  centers.  For  livestock 
processing  and  marketing  development,  the  Project  provides  commercial  credit,  technical 
backstopping,  and  various  inputs  such  as  live  animal  markets,  milk  chilling  centers, 
slaughterhouses,  slaughter  slabs,  and  several  livestock  product  processing  and  retailing 
facilities.  
 
A  study  will  also  be  carried  out  in  five  high-altitude  districts  to  establish  a  knowledge 
4. 
base and a livelihoods pilot program on livestock production, and a marketing system suited to 
the  underdeveloped,  poorly  accessible,  and  environmentally  sensitive  characteristics  of  the 
area.  
 
5. 
One  component  is  devoted  to  enhancing  the  capacity  of  farmers,  and  village-  and 
district-based livestock professionals and para-professionals, and strengthening the capacity of 
the Department of Livestock Services (DLS) and other relevant institutions in the project area 
to manage livestock and natural resources in an environmentally beneficial manner.  
 
C. 

Description of the Environment 

 

The project area ranges in altitude from 100 meters above sea level in the lowlands to 
6. 
7,893  meters  above  sea  level  in  Lamjung  district,  and  covers  lowland,  low  hills,  middle  hills, 
and  mountains.  The  project  area  can  be  divided  into  subtropical,  warm  temperate,  cool 
temperate,  sub-alpine,  and  alpine  climatic  zones.  Climatic  variations  are  extreme  due  to 
altitude,  aspect,  and  the  continentally  influenced  seasons.  Steep  slopes  and  high  rainfall 
intensity result in significant soil loss and landslides. Active alluvial soils are found in the river 
valleys  and  in  the  plains.  The  ratio  of  cultivated  to  noncultivated  area  in  the  western  project

55

area ranges from 3.17 to 63.6, and grassland occupies 3.2-31.5% of the land area. Livestock 
holdings  per  household  vary  from  3.1  to  7.0  units  in  the  project  area,  though  in  parts  of  the 
commercialization, processing, and marketing areas this figure reaches 100 livestock units.  
 
The biological diversity in the project area is of international importance in terms of the 
7. 
number  of  globally  threatened  species  of  wild  flora  and  fauna.  Tropical  riverine  forest  and 
tropical  evergreen  forest  dominate  the  lowland  areas,  and  suffer  greatly  from  lopping  for 
animal feed and felling for timber. The middle hill ecosystem (1,000-3,000 meters above sea 
level)  has  the  greatest  species  diversity.  Highlands  above  3,000  meters  are  the  meeting 
places  for  two  major  geographical  regions  in  which  38  ecosystems  are  found.  Within  the 
project area, several endangered plant and animal species are found. Blue sheep, wild goats, 
the  snow  leopard,  the  single-horn  rhinoceros,  and  freshwater  dolphins  are  notable.  Though 
humans  have  disturbed  much  of  the  forest  area,  large  tracts  are  still  intact.  There  are  no 
reports  of  plant  or  animal  species  that  have  become  extinct,  though  some  of  them  are 
endangered.   
 
8.  Within the project area are heritage sites of international importance such as the Royal 
Chitwan  National  Park,  wetlands  such  as  the  Koshi  Tappu  in  Sunsari  district  (a  wetlands 
habitat  for  waterfowl).  These  environmental  resources  are  protected  under  the  Forest  Act 
(1993), National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act (1973), and the Environment Protection 
Act (1996). The area is also rich in different aspects of human culture maintained by different 
ethnic groups.  
 
9.  
The  monsoon  is  the  main  rainy  season  (June-September)  when  over  80%  of  the  total 
precipitation and periods of high rainfall intensity occur. Over 6,000 rivers and streams drain 
the country. Several major rivers and a large number of their tributaries drain the project area. 
The Sapta Koshi in the east, Seti Gandaki, Kali Gandaki, and the Karnali are the major river 
systems.  
 
10. 
Ambient  air  quality  is  excellent  in  most  parts  of  the  project  area.  In  the  remote  areas, 
indoor  air  pollution  is  common  due  to  use  of  fuelwood  in  cooking.  In  the  urban  areas, 
particularly  in  the  Kathmandu  valley,  air  quality  is  deteriorating  because  of  vehicles  and 
industrialization.  Urbanized  areas  also  have  problems  with  water,  air,  and  noise  pollution. 
Deforestation, land degradation, and landslides are environmental hazards already occurring in 
the project area.  
 
D.  
 
11.   The  Project  may  produce  some  potential  long-term  impacts.  Native  species  (genetic 
biodiversity)  such  as  indigenous  forage  species  may  not  be  able  to  compete  with  faster 
growing  introduced  species,  and  the  latter  may  dominate.  Action  research  and  on-station 
evaluation of introduced species are warranted. These effects are not easy to mitigate as they 
are  directly  related  to  the  economic  benefit  requirements  of  poor  families.  The  impact  on  the 
environment  of  uncontrolled  grazing  and  trampling,  especially  in  forests,  grazing  lands,  and 
communal lands, is potentially a higher risk but also manageable. In product processing areas, 
the environmental problems are more related to pollution of water, air, and land, but they can 
be mitigated. 
 
12.   Stakeholders  need  to  internalize  the  concept  of  environmental  protection  and 
conservation  of  indigenous  species  at  each  stage  and  each  level  of  project  implementation. 
Stakeholders’  environmental  awareness  must  be  raised  and  their  capacity  to  manage  or 

Potential Environmental Impact and Mitigation Measures 

 

 56           Appendix 12 
 

reduce  environmental  impacts,  both  positive  and  negative,  must  be  improved.  Mitigation 
strategies  include  avoiding  environmental  damage  or  risk  through  proper  planning,  using 
environmentally  sound  technology  and  designs,  and  controlling  adverse  impacts  by  adopting 
proper management practices. 
 
13. 
The  Project  will  impact  on  the  environment,  especially  in  forested  areas  (used  as  a 
fodder source), grazing lands, communal lands (due to grazing, trampling, and littering), and on 
the genetic diversity of native species. However, the environmental impacts of these activities 
will  be  insignificant.  In  areas  where  processing  and  marketing  are  being  developed,  the 
environmental  impact  is  more  related  to  pollution  of  water,  air,  and  land.  Each  of  the  project 
components has been screened for significance and potential impacts. During implementation 
the environmental impacts of marketing and processing subprojects will be carefully screened. 
 
14. 
Land  Pollution.  Solid  waste  such  as  plastics,  packing  materials,  animal  manure, 
disposable  syringes,  and  animal  health  center  waste  can  pollute  the  land,  and  a  method  of 
separating biodegradable and recyclable elements of the wastes at source is required. These 
wastes  need  to  be  appropriately  disposed  of  in  biogas  plants,  in  designated  manure  and 
compost pits, or in trenches for burning waste. 
 
15.  Water  Pollution.  Without  guidelines  and  controls,  effluent  generated  by  dairy 
processing  plants,  slaughterhouses,  slaughter  slabs,  and  milk  chilling  centers  is  likely  to  be 
discharged into natural water bodies. Effluent, especially that containing chemicals, adversely 
affects  humans,  and  aquatic  and  plant  life.  Each  processing  unit  will  be  required  to  treat 
effluent,  and  treatment  systems  will  be  included  as  part  of  the  project  design  and  approval 
process.  Sedimentation,  oxidation,  or  treatment  ponds  where  the  discharge  will  meet 
acceptable biochemical oxygen demand levels will be implemented. 
 
16. 
Air  Pollution.  Air  pollution  occurs  within  and  around  intensive  livestock  production 
facilities  such  as  piggeries,  processing  units,  slaughter  sites,  and  marketing  areas.  Such 
impacts  can  be  minimized  by  maintaining  acceptable  hygiene  standards  (to  be  established 
under  the  Project),  spraying  water,  and  using  air  purifiers  and  other  air-circulating  devices 
within the units as appropriate. 
 
E. 
 
17. 
At the national level, the National Planning Commission and the Ministry of Population 
and  Environment  are  the  main  institutions  mandated  to  formulate  and  enforce  environment 
policy and law for the country. They also monitor trends and effects.  
 
18. 
The  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Cooperatives  (MOAC),  the  Department  of  Livestock 
Services  (DLS)  and  its  district  offices,  and  district  development  committees  will  be  directly 
involved  in  implementing  the  Project.  The  capacity  of  these  institutions  to  undertake  IEEs  of 
the  subprojects  is  weak,  as  none  of  the  institutions  have  staff  trained  in  environmental 
appraisal. Several private consultancy firms have project experience and could be contracted 
for  this  purpose.  Unfortunately,  almost  all  of  them  are  based  in  Kathmandu  and  do  not  have 
their  own  staff,  as  they  recruit  professionals  on  a  short-term  basis.  Therefore,  environmental 
monitoring  capacity  and  capability  are  largely  lacking  in  the  livestock  subsector  at  field  level, 
and any monitoring tends to be project related and project driven.  
 
19. 
The livestock productivity component will have insignificant environmental impacts. For 
the  livestock  processing  and  marketing  component,  a  four-step  environmental  management 

Institutional Requirements for Environmental Monitoring

57

process will be followed. First, a small environment monitoring team will be established in the 
planning  division  of  DLS,  and  DLS  staff  capability  will  be  strengthened  through  technical 
assistance, training, and awareness building. The monitoring team will be independent of the 
implementation  team.  It  will  visit  subprojects  that  are  potentially  environmentally  significant, 
hold  meetings,  and  prepare  terms  of  reference  for  the  subproject  IEE  as  required  by  the 
Environment Protection Act and regulations. Second, the IEE team will prepare a preliminary 
summary  of  relevant  information  and  checklist.  Third,  the  IEE  team  will  meet  with  relevant 
stakeholders to solicit their views on the subproject, and collect field level information through a 
consultative  process  as  required  by  the  environmental  regulation.  Fourth,  the  IEE  team  will 
analyze  the  information  collected,  recommend  appropriate  cost-effective  mitigation  measures 
to  cope  with  any  adverse  impacts,  while  enhancing  any  positive  impacts.  The  IEE  team  will 
prepare  a  report  on  its  findings  as  prescribed  by  the  Environment  Protection  Act  and  in  the 
Government’s  approved  format,  which  is  acceptable  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB). 
The  subproject  report  will  be  submitted  to  DLS,  MOAC,  and  ADB.  Training  in  environmental 
monitoring will also be given to district-based staff. Provision has been made for an appropriate 
budget to implement needed mitigation measures. 
 
F. 
 
20. 
There is a close relationship between poverty and environmental degradation. Most of 
the  project  area  has  a  high  incidence  of  poverty  and  communities  are  not  well  served  by 
government institutions. All the components of the proposed Project will be screened following 
ADB  guidelines.  The  IEE  shows  that  the  adverse  impacts  of  the  Project  are  not  severe,  and 
are  general  in  nature.  Therefore,  the  Project  does  not  need  further  study  such  as  an 
environmental impact assessment. Properly implementing prevailing laws and regulations and 
raising the awareness of stakeholders, and the prompt response of institutions to the adverse 
impacts can mitigate the likely adverse effects. Proper implementation of the recommendations 
and monitoring are essential to achieve the desired objectives.
